instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  problem
threads.message:
hi I have a board with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> going back a forward between diferent voltages , like 1,7 , 2.6 , 3.3 , .70 etc very fast , I change <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> , L7220 , <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> , <CAPACITOR>C7220</CAPACITOR> , so far and problem remain also I check pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and the voltage is same as <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> going back and forward.

I have green light , and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.6v

plz let me know that details you need to help me thank you

threads.message: hello master , <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is not fluctuating is steady 3.4V , anything I can try beside replacing SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  problem
threads.message:
hello I finally got a SMC for this board I didn't try to power it on SMC bypass , I didn't see your msg master duke , I replace the SMC , and the problem remain , (fuck I was able to replace a smc  thank you guys!) , anyway I remove <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> and the  <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> on pin 2 is 3.4v then I replace <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> thinking oh well the SMC was not the problem? , so must me <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> nothing ... problem remain.
So I remove <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> , and <RESISTOR>R7273</RESISTOR> to see if maybe something ahead was making the PM signal to be moving , but still nothing

 I was thinking to remove L7220 to see if that will make any chances on <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> signals ?
  What i should do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  problem
threads.message: i did remove L7220 and i feel like shit , SMC was good all the time i guess? , because without L7220   <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>  is steady 3.4v .... so some shit is going on at <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  to make <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> go crazy.... so i guess i should go and troubleshot the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area for crap?
